Chapter 4. Convex optimization problems

Notation

  • R=R, the set of real numbers

  • R+=R≥0, the set of nonnegative real numbers

  • R++=R>0​, , the set of positive real numbers

  • Rm×n=Rm×n, the set of m×n​ real matrices

  • Sn=Rsymn×n, the set of symmetric n×n real matrices

  • S+n=R⪰0n×n, the set of (symmetric) positive semidefinite n×n real matrices

  • S++n=R≻0n×n, the set of (symmetric) positive definite n×n real matrices

 

4.1 Optimization problems

4.1.1 Basic terminology

An optimization problem in standard form is one of the form

(4.1)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

The set of points for which the objective and all constraint functions are defined is called the domain D of (4.1).

A point x∈D is called feasible if fi(x)≤0 and hj(x)=0 for all i,j. The set of all feasible points is the feasible set.

The optimal value of (4.1) is defined as

p∗=inf{f0(x)∣x is feasible}∈R∪{±∞}

(following inf∅=∞). If there are feasible solutions xk with f0(xk)→−∞ as k→∞, then p∗=−∞ and we say (4.1) is unbounded below.

A feasible point x∗ is called optimal if f0(x∗)=p∗. The set of all optimal points is the optimal set. If there exists an optimal point for (4.1)​, we say the optimal value is achieved, and the problem is solvable.

A feasible point x is called ϵ-suboptimal if f0(x)≤p∗+ϵ for ϵ>0. The set of all ϵ-suboptimal points is the ϵ-suboptimal set.

A feasible point x is called locally optimal if there is an R>0 such that

f0(x)=inf{f0(z)∣z is feasible, ∥z−x∥2≤R}.

If f0(x)≡0, the optimal value is either 0 (if the feasible set is nonempty) or ∞ (if the feasible set is empty). We call this the feasibility problem

findxsubject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

 

4.1.2 Expressing problems in standard form

We can solve the maximization problem

(4.2)maximizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

by minimizing −f0(x)​ subject to the constraints. The optimal value of (4.2) is defined as

p∗=sup{f0(x)∣x is feasible}∈R∪{±∞}

and a feasible point x is ϵ-suboptimal if f0(x)≥p∗−ϵ for ϵ>0.

 

4.1.3 Equivalent problems

Change of variables

Suppose ϕ:Rn→Rn is one-to-one, with image covering D. Then the problem

(4.4)minimizef~0(z)≡f0(ϕ(z))subject tof~i(z)≡fi(ϕ(z))≤0,1≤i≤mh~j(z)≡hj(ϕ(z))=0,1≤j≤p

and (4.1) are equivalent: If x solves (4.1) then z=ϕ−1(x) solves (4.4); if z solves (4.4) then x=ϕ(z)​ solves (4.1).

 

Transformation of objective and constraint functions

Suppose ψ0:R→R is monotone increasing on the image of f0, and ψi:R→R satisfy ψi(u)≤0⇔u≤0 and ξj:R→R satisfy ξj(u)=0⇔u=0. Then the problem

minimizef~0(x)≡ψ0(f0(x))subject tof~i(x)≡ψi(fi(x))≤0,1≤i≤mh~j(x)≡ξj(hj(x))=0,1≤j≤p

and (4.1) are equivalent: The feasible sets are identical, and the optimal points are identical.

 

Slack variables

Notice that fi(x)≤0 if and only if there is an si≥0 such that fi(x)+si=0. The new variable si is called the slack variable associated with fi(x)≤0. Then the problem

(4.7)minimizef0(x)subject tosi≥0,1≤i≤mfi(x)+si=0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

is equivalent to (4.1).

 

Eliminating equality constraints

If we can explicitly parametrize all solutions of hj(x)=0 using some parameter z∈Rk​, then we can eliminate hj(x)=0 from the problem, as follows.

Suppose ϕ:Rk→Rn is such that x∈Rn satisfies hj(x)=0 for all 1≤j≤p if and only if there is some z∈Rk with x=ϕ(z). Then the problem

minimizef0(ϕ(z))subject tofi(ϕ(z))≤0,1≤i≤m

is equivalent to (4.1).

 

Eliminating linear equality constraints

The process of eliminating variables can be described more explicitly when the equality constraints are all linear, i.e., Ax=b for some A∈Rp×n.

Assume that the original problem (4.1) is feasible, and let x0∈Rn such that Ax0=b.

Let F∈Rn×k be a matrix of which the columns are a basis of the null space N(A). Then the general solution of Ax=b is given by Fz+x0 for z∈Rk. Note that x∈N(A), i.e., Ax=0 if and only if there is some z∈Rk with Fz=x. Then the problem

minimizef0(Fz+x0)subject tofi(Fz+x0)≤0,1≤i≤m

is equivalent to (4.1).

 

Introducing equality constraints

Consider the problem

minimizef0(A0x+b0)subject tofi(Aix+bi)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

where Ai∈Rki×n and fi:Rki→R. In this problem the objective and inequality constraints are given as compositions of fi with affine transformations Aix+bi.

We introduce new variables yi∈Rki, as well as new equality constraints yi=Aix+bi for 0≤i≤m, and form the equivalent problem

minimizef0(y0)subject tofi(yi)≤0,1≤i≤myi=Aix+bi,0≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

This problem has ∑i=0mki new variables and ∑i=0mki new equality constraints. However, the objective (y0) and inequality constraints (y1,…,ym) are independent, i.e., involve different optimization variables.

 

Optimizing over some variables

Suppose x∈Rn is partitioned as x=(x1,x2) with xi∈Rni and n1+n2=n. Consider the problem

(4.9)minimizef0(x1,x2)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1f~i(x2)≤0,1≤i≤m2.

Define f~0(x1)=inf{f0(x1,z)∣f~i(z)≤0 for 1≤i≤m2}. The problem (4.9) is then equivalent to

(4.10)minimizef~0(x1)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1.

 

Epigraph problem form

The epigraph form of (4.1) is the problem

(4.11)minimizetsubject tof0(x)−t≤0fi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

which is equivalent to (4.1): (x,t) is optimal for (4.11) if and only if x is optimal for (4.1) and t=f0(x). Note that the objective function of (4.11) is linear.

 

4.1.4 Parameter and oracle problem descriptions

Parameter problem description

The objective and constraint functions have some analytical or closed form, i.e., are given by a formula or expression that involves the variable x​ as well as some parameters.

For example, f0(x)=12xTPx+qTx+r. Here, P∈Rsymn×n, q∈Rn and r∈R are problem parameters.

 

Oracle problem description

The objective and constraint functions are described by oracle models (which are also called black box or subroutine models).

In an oracle model, we do not know f explicitly, but can evaluate f(x) (and usually also some derivatives). This is referred to as querying the oracle, and is usually associated with some cost, such as time.

 

4.2 Convex optimization

A function f:Rn→R is convex if Domf is a convex set and

(3.1)f(θx+(1−θ)y)≤θf(x)+(1−θ)f(y)

for all x,y∈Domf and θ∈[0,1]​.

A function f is strictly convex if strict inequality holds in (3.1) whenever x≠y and θ∈[0,1]. We say f is concave if −f is convex, and strictly concave if −f​​ is strictly convex.

The α-sublevel set of a function f:Rn→R is defined as

Sα={x∈Domf∣f(x)≤α}.

Sublevel sets of a convex function are convex, for any α∈R. The converse is not true. For example, f(x)=−ex is not convex on R but all its sublevel sets are convex.

 

4.2.1 Convex optimization problems in standard form

A convex optimization problem is one of the form

(4.15)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=ajTx−bj=0,1≤j≤p,

where fi are convex functions for all 0≤i≤m​, and hj are affine for all 1≤j≤p.

We may assume without loss of generality that aj≠0: If aj=bj=0, the j-th equality constraint can be deleted; if aj=0 and bj≠0, the j-th equality constraint is inconsistent and the problem is infeasible.

The feasible set of a convex optimization problem is convex, since it is the intersection of the (convex) domain D with m (convex) sublevel sets and p​ hyperplanes. Thus, we minimize a convex objective function over a convex set.

The ϵ-suboptimal sets are convex. In particular, the optimal set is convex.

If the objective is strictly convex, the optimal set contains at most one point.

 

Concave maximization problems
(4.16)maximizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=ajTx−bj=0,1≤j≤p,

where f0 is concave and fi are convex for all 1≤i≤m. This problem can be solved by minimizing −f0.

 

4.2.2 Local and global optima

A fundamental property of convex optimization problems is that any locally optimal point is also (globally) optimal.

Proof. Suppose x is locally optimal, i.e., x is feasible and for some R>0,

(4.19)f0(x)=inf{f0(z)∣z is feasible, ∥z−x∥2≤R}.

Now suppose x is not globally optimal. Then there is a feasible y such that f0(y)<f0(x) and ∥y−x∥>R. Consider the point z given by

z=(1−θ)x+θywhere θ=R2∥y−x∥2.

Then z is feasible and ∥z−x∥2=R2<R, so f0(x)≤f0(z). However,

f0(z)≤(1−θ)f0(x)+θf0(y)<f0(x),

which contradicts (4.19). Hence, x is globally optimal.

 

4.2.3 An optimality criterion for differentiable f0​

First-order conditions for convexity

Suppose f is differentiable. Then f is convex if and only if Domf is convex and

(4.20)f(y)≥f(x)+∇f(x)T(y−x)

holds for all x,y∈Domf (see §3.1.3).

Suppose that the objective f0 in a convex optimization problem is differentiable. Then x is optimal if and only if x is feasible and

(4.21)∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0for all feasible y.

 

Proof. (⇐) If x is feasible and satisfies (4.21), then f0(y)−f0(x)=∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0 for all feasible y. Thus x is optimal.

(⇒) Suppose x is optimal, but (4.21) does not hold, i.e., ∇f0(x)T(y−x)<0 for some feasible y​. Consider the feasible path z(t)=ty+(1−t)x for t∈[0,1]. Then for small t>0, we have f0(z(t))<f0(x), since

ddtf0(z(t))|t=0=∇f0(x)T(y−x)<0.

 

Unconstrained problems

For an unconstrained problem, (4.21) reduces to the well-known necessary and sufficient condition

(4.22)∇f0(x)=0

for x to be optimal​.

There are several possible situations, depending on the number of solutions of (4.22).

  • If there are no solutions of (4.22), there are no optimal points; the optimal value of the problem is not achieved.

    1. The problem is unbounded below.

    2. The optimal value is finite, but not achieved.

  • We can have multiple solutions of (4.22), in which case each such solution is a minimizer of f0​.

The analytic center of a polyhedron P={x∣Ax⪯b} is defined as a point inside P that maximizes the product of distances to the sides. The distance of x∈P to each side is (b−aiTx)/∥ai∥ so that the analytic center is x which maximizes ∏i(b−aiTx).

 

Problems with equality constraints only

Consider the problem

minimizef0(x)subject toAx=b.

We assume that the (affine) feasible set is nonempty. The optimality condition (4.21) for a feasible x can be expressed as

∇f0(x)+ATν=0for some ν∈Rp.

Proof. Let x be feasible, i.e., Ax=b. Then every feasible y has the form y=x+v for some v∈N(A). Therefore, (4.21) can be expressed as

∇f0(x)T(y−x)=∇f0(x)Tv≥0for all v∈N(A).

Since N(A) is a subspace, ∇f0(x)⊥N(A) ⇒ ∇f0(x)∈N(A)⊥=R(AT).

Together with Ax=b (since x​​ is feasible), this is the classical Lagrange multiplier optimality condition:

f0(x)+(Ax−b)Tν.

 

Minimization over the nonnegative orthant (e.g. 사분면 or 팔분면)

Consider the problem

minimizef0(x)subject tox⪰0.

The optimality condition (4.21) can be expressed as

x⪰0,∇f0(x)⪰0,xi(∇f0(x))i=0 for 1≤i≤n.

Proof. Note that (4.21) can be expressed as

x⪰0,∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0for all y⪰0.

The term ∇f0(x)Ty→−∞ on y⪰0, unless ∇f0(x)⪰0. Thus the condition reduces to −∇f0(x)Tx≥0. But x⪰0 and ∇f0(x)⪰0, so we must have ∇f0(x)Tx=0.

The last condition is called complementarity, since it means that the sparsity patterns (i.e., the set of indices corresponding to nonzero components) of x and ∇f0(x)​ are complementary (i.e., have empty intersection).

 

4.2.4 Equivalent convex problems

Eliminating equality constraints

For a convex problem, the equality constraints must be linear, i.e., Ax=b.

In this case, recall that (4.1) is equivalent to the problem

minimizef0(Fz+x0)subject tofi(Fz+x0)≤0,1≤i≤m,

where F∈Rk×n such that R(F)⊆N(A).

Since the composition of a convex function with an affine function is convex, eliminating equality constraints preserves convexity of a problem.

In many cases, however, it is better to retain the equality constraints, since eliminating them can make the problem harder to understand and analyze, or ruin the efficiency of an algorithm that solves it.

 

Introducing equality constraints

Consider the problem

minimizef0(A0x+b0)subject tofi(Aix+bi)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p

We introduce new variables yi∈Rki, as well as new equality constraints yi=Aix+bi for 0≤i≤m, and form the equivalent problem

minimizef0(y0)subject tofi(yi)≤0,1≤i≤myi=Aix+bi,0≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

If we introduce new variables and linear equality constraints into a convex optimization problem, the resulting problem will also be convex.

 

Slack variables

The slack variables si associated with fi(x)≤0 give the equivalent problem

minimizef0(x)subject tosi≥0,1≤i≤mfi(x)+si=0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

Since equality constraint must be affine in a convex problem, we must have fi affine for 1≤i≤m.

 

Epigraph problem form

The epigraph form of (4.1) is the problem

minimizetsubject tof0(x)−t≤0fi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mhj(x)=0,1≤j≤p.

The objective is linear (hence convex) and the new constraint f0(x)−t​ is also convex, so the epigraph form problem is convex as well.

The epigraph form of a convex problem has several practical uses. We can simplify theoretical analysis. It can also simplify algorithm development.

 

Minimizing over some variables

Suppose x∈Rn is partitioned as x=(x1,x2) with xi∈Rni and n1+n2=n. Consider the problem

(4.9)minimizef0(x1,x2)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1f~i(x2)≤0,1≤i≤m2.

Define f~0(x1)=inf{f0(x1,z)∣f~i(z)≤0 for 1≤i≤m2}. The problem (4.9) is then equivalent to

(4.10)minimizef~0(x1)subject tofi(x1)≤0,1≤i≤m1.

If f is convex in (x,y), and C is a convex nonempty set, then g(x)=infy∈Cf(x,y) is convex in x, provided g(x)>−∞ for all x, (see §3.2.5).

Minimizing a convex function over some variables preserves convexity. Therefore, if f0 in (4.9) is convex in (x1,x2), and fi and f~i are convex, then the equivalent problem (4.10) is convex.

 

4.2.5 Quasiconvex optimization

A function f:R→R is called quasiconvex if its domain and all its sublevel sets Sα={x∈Domf∣f(x)≤α} for α∈R​​ are convex.

A function is quasiconcave if −f is quasiconvex. A function that is both quasiconvex and quasiconcave is called quasilinear.

If the objective f0 in a convex optimization problem (4.15) is quasiconvex, we have a (standard form) quasiconvex optimization problem

(4.24)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mAx=b,

where f0 is quasiconvex and fi are convex for 1≤i≤m.

In a similar way, if f0 in a concave optimization problem (4.16) is quasiconcave, we have a (standard form) quasiconcave optimization problem

maximizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mAx=b,

where f0 is quasiconcave and fi are convex for 1≤i≤m.

The ϵ-suboptimal sets are also convex for a quasiconvex optimization problem. In particular, the optimal set is convex.

 

Locally optimal solutions and optimality conditions

A quasiconvex optimization problem can have locally optimal solutions that are not (globally) optimal.

First-order conditions for quasiconvexity

A differentiable function f:Rn→R with convex domain is quasiconvex if and only if

(3.20)f(y)≤f(x)⟹∇f(x)T(y−x)≤0for all x,y∈Domf.

In a convex optimization problem, x is optimal if and only if x is feasible and

(4.21)∇f0(x)T(y−x)≥0for all feasible y

The first-order condition for quasiconvexity implies that x is optimal if x is feasible and

(4.25)∇f0(x)T(y−x)>0for all y≠x feasible.

  • (4.25) is only sufficient for optimality, whereas (4.21) is necessary and sufficient.

  • (4.25) requires ∇f0≠0, whereas (4.21) does not.

 

Quasiconvex optimization via convex feasibility problems

If f is quasiconvex, there exists a family of convex functions ϕt such that

(3.23)f(x)≤t⟺ϕt(x)≤0,

i.e., the t-sublevel set of f is the 0-sublevel set of ϕt, (see §3.4.5).

Such a representation always exists, we can take

ϕt(x)={0,f(x)≤t,∞otherwise.

However, we are usually interested in a family ϕt with nice properties, such as differentiability.

Let ϕt be a family of convex functions that satisfy f0(x)≤t⟺ϕt(x)≤0 and also ϕs(x)≤ϕt(x) whenever s≥t.

Let p∗ be the optimal value of the quasiconvex optimization problem (4.24). Consider the convex feasibility problem for a given value t,

(4.26)findxsubject toϕt(x)≤0fi(x)≤0,1≤i≤mAx=b.

If (4.26) has a feasible point x, then p∗≤t. Conversely, if (4.26) is infeasible, then p∗≥t.

It follows that exactly k=⌈log2⁡((u−l)/ϵ)⌉ iterations are required before the algorithm terminates, since u−l2k≤ϵ.

 

4.3 Linear optimization problems

If the objective and all constraint functions are affine, the problem is called a linear program (LP). A general linear program has the form

(4.27)minimizecTx+dsubject toGx⪰hAx=b,

where G∈Rm×n and A∈Rp×n. Linear programs are, of course, convex optimization problems.

It is common to omit the constant d in the objective function, since it does not affect the optimal set.

 

Standard and inequality form linear programs

In a standard form LP

(4.28)minimizecTxsubject toAx=bx⪰0.

If the LP has no equality constraints, it is called an inequality form LP

(4.29)minimizecTxsubject toAx⪯b.

 

Converting LPs to standard form

It is sometimes useful to transform (4.27) to (4.28).

  1. Introduce slack variables si for the inequalities, which results in

    minimizecTx+dsubject toGx+s=hAx=bs⪰0.

  2. Express x=x+−x− for x+,x−∈R≥0. This yields an LP in standard form.

    minimizecTx+−cTx−+dsubject toGx+−Gx−+s=hAx+−Ax−=bx+⪰0,x−⪰0,s⪰0.

 

4.3.1 Examples

Diet problem

A healthy diet contains m different nutrients in quantities at least equal to b1…,bm. We can compose such a diet by choosing nonnegative quantities x1,…,xn of n different foods. One unit quantity of food j contains an amount aij of nutrient i, and has a cost of cj.

We want to determine the cheapest diet that satisfies the nutritional requirements. The problem can be formulated as the LP

minimizecTxsubject toAx⪰bx⪰0.
Chebyshev center of a polyhedron

Consider the problem of finding the largest Euclidean ball (e.g., 내접원) that lies in a polyhedron

P={x∈Rn∣aiTx≤bi,1≤i≤m}.

The center of the optimal ball (called the Chebyshev center of P) can be determined by solving the LP

maximizersubject toaiTxc+r∥ai∥2≤bi,1≤i≤m.

Proof. The constraint {xc+u∣∥u∥2≤r}⊆P, i.e., ∥u∥2≤r⇒aiT(xc+u)≤bi can be written as

aiTxc+sup{aiTu∣∥u∥2≤r}=aiTxc+r∥ai∥2≤bi.

 

Dynamic activity planning (skip)

 

Chebyshev inequalities

Consider a probability distribution p∈Rn for a discrete random variable x on {u1,…,un}⊆R, where pk=prob(x=uk). Then p⪰0 and 1Tp=1. Conversely, if p∈Rn satisfies p⪰0 and 1Tp=1, it defines a probability distribution for x.

Suppose we know upper and lower bounds on E[fi]=∑kpkfi(uk) for some functions fi of x. It can be expressed as linear inequality constraints on p,

αi≤aiTp≤βi,1≤i≤m.

The problem is to give lower and upper bounds on E[f0]=a0Tp, where f0 is some function of x. The optimal value of the LP

minimizea0Tpsubject top⪰0,1Tp=1αi≤aiTp≤βi,1≤i≤m.

gives the lowest possible value of E[f0] for any distribution. Moreover, the bound is sharp: The optimal solution achieves the lower bound. In a similar way, we can find the best upper bound by maximizing a0Tp subject to the same constraints.

 

Piecewise-linear minimization

Consider the (unconstrained) problem of minimizing the piecewise-linear, convex function

f(x)=max1≤i≤m(aiTx+bi).

This problem can be transformed to an equivalent LP (the epigraph problem)

minimizetsubject toaiTx+bi≤t,1≤i≤m.

 

4.3.2 Linear-fractional programming

The problem of minimizing a ratio of affine functions over a polyhedron is called a linear-fractional problem

(4.32)minimizef0(x)subject toGx⪯hAx=b

where f0(x)=cTx+deTx+f and Domf0={x∣eTx+f>0}​​.

The objective function f0​ is quasiconvex (in fact, quasilinear) so (4.32) is a quasiconvex optimization problem.

 

Transforming to a linear program

If the feasible set {x∣Gx⪯h,Ax=b,eTx+f>0}≠∅, then (4.32) can be transformed to an equivalent LP

(4.33)minimizecTy+dzsubject toGy−hz⪯0Ay−bz=0eTy+fz=1z≥0.

Proof. Let p∗ and q∗ be the optimal value of (4.32) and (4.33), respectively. Then p∗=q∗.

(p∗≥q∗) If x is feasible in (4.32), then the pair y=xeTx+f and z=1eTx+f>0 is feasible in (4.33) with the same objective value cTy+dz=f0(x).

(p∗≤q∗) Suppose (y,z) is feasible in (4.33). If z≠0, then x=y/z is feasible in (4.32) with the same objective value f0(x)=cTy+dz. On the other hands, if z=0, let x0 is a feasible for (4.32). Then x=x0+ty is feasible in (4.32) for all t≥0. Moreover, limt→∞f0(x0+ty)=cTy/eTy=cTy+dz, since eTy+fz=1 and z=0. Thus we can find feasible points in (4.32) with objective values arbitrarily close to the objective value of (y,z)​.

 

Generalized linear-fractional programming

A generalization of (4.32) is the generalized linear-fractional program in which

f0(x)=max1≤i≤rciTx+dieiTx+fi,Domf0={x∣eiTx+fi>0 for 1≤i≤r}.

The objective function f0(x) is the pointwise maximum of r​​ quasiconvex functions, and therefore quasiconvex, so this problem is quasiconvex.

A nonnegative weighted maximum of quasiconvex functions, i.e., f=max{w1f1,…,wmfm} with wi≥0 and fi quasiconvex, is quasiconvex, (see §3.4.4.)

(∵) The α-sublevel set of f is the intersection of the α-sublevel sets of wifi.

 

4.4 Quadratic optimization problems

The convex optimization problem (4.15) is called a quadratic program (QP) if the objective f0​ is (convex) quadratic, and the constraint functions are affine.

(4.34)minimize12xTPx+qTx+rsubject toGx⪯hAx=b,

where P∈R⪰0n×n, G∈Rm×n, and A∈Rp×n​.

If the objective in (4.15) as well as the inequality constraint functions are (convex) quadratic, the problem is called a quadratically constrained quadratic program (QCQP).

(4.35)minimize12xTP0x+q0Tx+r0subject to12xTPix+qiTx+ri≤0,1≤i≤mAx=b,

where Pi∈R⪰0n×n and A∈Rp×n​. Notice that LP ⊂ QP ⊂ QCQP.

 

4.4.1 Examples

Least-squares and regression

The problem of minimizing

∥Ax−b∥22=xTATAx−2bTAx+bTb

is an (unconstrained) QP (called regression analysis or least-squares approximation), which has the well known analytical solution x=A†b, where A† is the pseudo-inverse of A.

When linear inequality constraints are added (called constrained regression or constrained least-square), there is no longer a simple analytical solution. As an example of QP,

minimize∥Ax−b∥22subject toli≤xi≤ui,1≤i≤n.

 

Distance between polyhedra

The (Euclidean) distance between the two polyhedra Pi={x∈Rn∣Aix⪯bi} for i=1,2 is defined as

dist(P1,P2)=inf{∥x1−x2∥2|xi∈Pi for i=1,2}.

To find dist(P1,P2), we can solve the QP

minimize∥x1−x2∥22subject toAixi⪯bi,i=1,2.

This problem is infeasible if and only if one of Pi=∅.

The optimal value is zero if and only if P1∩P2≠∅, in which case the optimal x1=x2∈P1∩P2. Otherwise the optimal x1∈P1 and x2∈P2 are closest to each other.

 

Bounding variance

Consider a probability distribution p∈Rn for a discrete random variable x on {u1,…,un}⊆R, where pk=prob(x=uk).

For a function f on x, we have E[f]=∑kfkpk where fk=f(uk), and the variance of f is

Var[f]=E[f2]−E[f]2=∑kfk2pk−(∑kfkpk)2,

which is a concave quadratic function on p​.

We can maximize the variance of f, subject to the given prior information, by solving the QP

maximize∑kfk2pk−(∑kfkpk)2subject top⪰0,1Tp=1αi≤aiTp≤βi,1≤i≤m.

 

Linear program with random cost

We consider an LP

minimizecTxsubject toGx⪯hAx=b.

Suppose the cost vector c∈Rn is random, with mean value c¯ and covariance Σ=E[(c−c¯)(c−c¯)T]​.

For x∈Rn, the cost cTx is a (scalar) random variable with mean E[cTx]=c¯Tx and variance

Var[cTx]=E[(cTx−E[cTx])2]=xTΣx.

In general, there is a trade-off between small expected cost and small cost variance. One way to take variance into account is to minimize a linear combination

E[cTx]+γVar[cTx]=c¯Tx+γxTΣx

which is called the risk-sensitive cost. The parameter γ≥0 is called the risk-aversion (or risk-avoiding) parameter. For γ>0, we are willing to trade off an increase in expected cost for a sufficiently large decrease in cost variance.

To minimize the risk-sensitive cost we solve the QP

minimizec¯Tx+γxTΣxsubject toGx⪯hAx=b.

 

Markowitz portfolio optimization (skip)

We consider a classical portfolio problem with n assets or stocks held over a period of time.

Let xi denote the amount of asset i held throughout the period, with xi in dollars, at the price at the beginning of the period. A normal long position in asset i corresponds to xi>0; a short position in asset i corresponds to xi<0.

Let pi denote the relative price change of asset i over the period. The overall return on the portfolio is r=pTx (given in dollars). The optimization variable is the portfolio vector x∈Rn.

We take a stochastic model for price changes: p∈Rn is a random vector with known mean p¯ and covariance Σ. Therefore with portfolio x∈Rn, the return r is a (scalar) random variable with mean p¯Tx and variance xTΣx. The choice of portfolio x involves a trade-off between the mean of the return, and its variance.

The classical portfolio optimization problem, introduced by Markowitz, is the QP

minimizexTΣxsubject top¯Tx≥rmin1Tx=1,x⪰0.

Many extensions are possible, see p.156.

 

4.4.2 Second-order cone programming

A problem that is closely related to QP is the second-order cone program (SOCP)

(4.36)minimizefTxsubject to∥Aix+bi∥2≤ciTx+di,1≤i≤mFx=g,

where Ai∈Rni×n and F∈Rp×n. We call a constraint of the form

∥Ax+b∥2≤cTx+d

where A∈Rk×n, a second-order cone constraint, since it is the same as requiring the affine function (Ax+b,cTx+d) to lie in the second-order cone Ck+1={(x,t)∣x∈Rk,t∈R,∥x∥2≤t}⊆Rk+1​​.

Notice that LP ⊂ QP ⊂ QCQP ⊂ SOCP. When ci=0 for 1≤i≤m, the SOCP (4.36) is equivalent to a QCQP. Similarly, if Ai=0 for 1≤i≤m, the SOCP (4.36) reduces to a (general) LP.

 

Robust linear programming

We consider a LP in equality form

minimizecTxsubject toaiTx≤bi,1≤i≤m.

in which there is some uncertainty or variation in the parameters c,ai,bi.

To simplify the exposition, we assume that c and bi are fixed, and that

ai∈Ei={a¯i+Piu∣∥u∥2≤1},

where Pi∈Rn×n. (If Pi is singular, we obtain "flat" ellipsoids of dimension rankPi; Pi=0 means that ai​ is known perfectly.)

We require that the constraints be satisfied for all possible values of the parameters ai, which leads us to the robust linear program

(4.37)minimizecTxsubject toaiTx≤bi for all ai∈Ei,1≤i≤m.

The robust linear constraint can be expressed as a second-order cone constraint

sup{aiTx∣ai∈Ei}=a¯iTx+sup{uTPiTx∣∥u∥2≤1}=a¯iTx+∥PiTx∥2≤bi.

Hence the robust LP (4.37) can be expressed as the SOCP

minimizecTxsubject toa¯iTx+∥PiTx∥2≤bi,1≤i≤m.

Note that the additional norm terms act as regularization terms; they prevent x from being large in directions with considerable uncertainty in the parameters ai.

 

Linear programming with random constraints

The robust LP described above can also be considered in a statistical framework.

Suppose that ai are independent Gaussian random vectors, with mean a¯i and covariance Σi.

For η≥0.5, the problem

minimizecTxsubject toprob(aiTx≤bi)≥η,1≤i≤m

can be expressed as the SOCP

minimizecTxsubject toa¯iTx+Φ−1(η)∥Σi1/2x∥2≤bi,1≤i≤m,

where Φ(z) is the cumulative distribution of a zero mean unit variance Gaussian random variable. Note that Φ−1(η)≥0 by assumption that η≥0.5. (See p.158 for proof.)

 

Minimal surface

Consider a differentiable function f:R2→R with Domf=C. The surface area of its graph is given by

A=∫C1+∥∇f(x)∥22dx=∫C∥(∇f(x),1)∥2dx,

which is a convex functional of f.

The minimal surface problem is to find f that minimizes A subject to some constraints, for example, some given values of f on the boundary of C​.

Let C=[0,1]2 and denote by fi,j=f(iK,jK) for 0≤i,j≤K. Then approximate expressions for ∇f and A are

∇f(x)≈K[fi+1,j−fi,jfi,j+1−fi,j]andA≈Adisc=1K2∑i,j‖[K(fi+1,j−fi,j)K(fi,j+1−fi,j)1]‖2.

The discretized are approximation Adisc is a convex function of fi,j.

As an example, we consider the problem of finding the minimal area surface with fixed boundary values lj on the left and rj on the right edges of the square

(4.40)minimizeAdiscsubject tof0,j=lj,0≤j≤KfK,j=rj,0≤j≤K.

We can transform (4.40) into an SOCP by introducing new variables ti,j​

minimize1K2∑i,jti,jsubject to‖[K(fi+1,j−fi,j)K(fi,j+1−fi,j)1]‖2≤ti,j,0≤i,j≤Kf0,j=lj,0≤j≤KfK,j=rj,0≤j≤K.

 

4.5 Geometric programming

4.5.1 Monomials and posynomials

A function f:R⪰0n→R defined as f(x)=cx1a1x2a2⋯xnan where c>0 and ai∈R​ is called a monomial function. Monomials are closed under multiplication and division.

A finite sum of monomials f(x)=∑k=1Kckx1a1kx2a2k⋯xnank where ck>0 is called a posynomial function (with K​​ terms). Posynomials are closed under addition, multiplication, and nonnegative scaling.

If a posynomial is multiplied (or divided) by a monomial, the result is a posynomial.

 

4.5.2 Geometric programming

An optimization problem of the form

(4.43)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)≤1,1≤i≤mhj(x)=1,1≤j≤p,

where fi are posynomials for 0≤i≤m and hj are monomials for 1≤j≤p​, is called a geometric program (GP) (in posynomial form).

The domain of this problem is D=R≻0n because of hj(x)=1 so that the constraint x⪰0 is implicit.

 

Extensions of geometric programming

If f is a posynomial and h is a (nonzero) monomial, then the constraint f(x)≤h(x) can be handled by expressing it as f(x)/h(x)≤1​.

In a similar way, if h1 and h2 are both (nonzero) monomial functions, then we can handle the equality constraint h1(x)=h2(x) by expressing it as h1(x)/h2(x)=1​.

We can maximize a (nonzero) monomial objective function, by minimizing its inverse.

 

4.5.3 Geometric program in convex form

Geometric programs are not (in general) convex optimization problems, but they can be transformed to convex problems by a change of variables and a transformation of the objective and constraint functions.

  • The change of variables yi=log⁡xi so xi=eyi turns a monomial function into the exponential of an affine function. (∵) f(x)=cx1a1x2a2⋯xnan=eaTy+b, where b=log⁡c

  • Similarly, a posynomial becomes a sum of exponentials of affine functions.

We transform the objective and constraints of (4.43) by taking the logarithm.

(4.44)minimizef~0(y)=log⁡(∑kea0kTy+b0k)subject tof~i(y)=log⁡(∑keaikTy+bik)≤0,1≤i≤mh~j(y)=gjTy+hj=0,1≤j≤p,

Since f~i are convex (see §3.1.5 Examples, Log-sum-exp) and h~j​​ are affine, this problem is a convex optimization problem, called a geometric program in convex form.

If the posynomial objective and constraints all are monomials, then (4.44) reduces to a (general) linear program. We can therefore consider GP to be a generalization or extension of LP.

 

4.5.4 Examples

Frobenius norm diagonal scaling

Consider a matrix M∈Rn×n, and a linear function y=Mu.

Suppose we scale the coordinates, u~=Du, where D=diag(d) is diagonal with di>0. In the new coordinates y=Mu is given by y~=Dy=DMD−1u~​.

We want to choose the scaling in such a way that DMD−1 is small. We will use the Frobenius norm (squared) to measure the size of the matrix.

∥DMD−1∥F2≡tr[(DMD−1)T(DMD−1)]=∑i,j(DMD−1)ij2=∑i,jMij2di2/dj2

Since this is a posynomial in d, the problem of choosing the scaling d to minimize the Frobenius norm is an unconstrained GP

minimize∑i,jMij2di2dj−2.

4.6 Generalized inequality constraints

A set C is called a cone if θx∈C for all x∈C and θ>0​.

A cone K⊆Rn is called a proper cone if

  • K is convex, closed, solid (has nonempty interior), and pointed (contains no line).

A proper cone K can be used to define a generalized inequality, which is a partial ordering on Rn defined by x⪯Ky⟺y−x∈K.

Similarly, we define a strict partial ordering x≺Ky⟺y−x∈intK​.

When K=R≥0, the partial ordering ⪯K is the usual ordering ≤ on R, and the strict partial ordering ≺K is the same as the usual strict ordering < on R. (See §2.4.1.)

A (standard form) convex optimization problem with generalized inequality constraints is

(4.48)minimizef0(x)subject tofi(x)⪯Ki0,1≤i≤mAx=b,

where f0:Rn→R and fi:Rn→Rki with proper cones Ki⊆Rki for 1≤i≤m​.

Problem (4.15) is a special case with Ki=R≥0 for 1≤i≤m.

Many of the results for ordinary convex optimization problems hold for problems with generalized inequalities.

  • The feasible set, any sublevel set, and the optimal set are convex.

  • Any point that is locally optimal for (4.48) is globally optimal.

  • The optimality condition for differentiable f0 holds without any change.

  • Convex optimization problems with generalized inequality constraints can often be solved as easily as ordinary convex optimization problems. (See Chapter 11. Interior-point methods.)

 

4.6.1 Conic form problems

(4.49)minimizecTxsubject toFx+g⪯K0Ax=b.

When K=R⪰0m, the nonnegative orthant, (4.48) reduces to a LP. We can view conic form problems as a generalization of LP.

 

4.6.2 Semidefinite programming

When K=R⪰0k×k, the cone of positive semidefinite k×k matrices, (4.49) is called a semidefinite program (SDP)

(4.50)minimizecTxsubject tox1F1+⋯+xnFn+G⪯0Ax=b,

where G,F1,…,Fn∈Rsymk×k, and A∈Rp×n.

If the matrices G,F1,…,Fn are all diagonal, the linear matrix inequality (LMI) is equivalent to a set of n linear inequalities, and (4.50) reduces to a LP.

 

Standard and inequality form semidefinite programs

Recall that tr(CX)=∑i,jCijXij is the form of a general real-valued linear function on Rsymn×n.

A standard form SDP has linear equality constraints and a (matrix) nonnegativity constraint on X∈Rsymn×n.

(4.51)minimizetr(CX)subject totr(AiX)=bi,1≤i≤pX⪰0,

where C,A1,…,Ap∈Rsymn×n​.

An inequality form SDP has no equality constraints and one LMI.

minimizecTxsubject tox1A1+⋯+xnAn⪯B,

where B,A1,…,An∈Rsymn×n and c∈Rn.

 

Multiple LMIs and linear inequalities
minimizecTxsubject toF(i)(x)=x1F1(i)+⋯+xnFn(i)+G(i)⪯0,1≤i≤KGx⪯h,Ax=b.

has linear objective, linear inequality and inequality constraints, and several LMI constraints.

Such problems are readily transformed into an SDP, by forming a large block diagonal LMI from the individual LMIs and linear inequalities.

minimizecTxsubject todiag(Gx−h,F(1)(x),…,F(K)(x))⪯0Ax=b.

 

4.6.3 Examples

Second-order cone program

The SOCP (4.36) can be expressed as a conic form problem

minimizecTxsubject to−(Aix+bi,ciTx+do)⪯Ki0,1≤i≤mFx⪯g,

where Ki={(y,t)∈Rni+1|∥y∥2≤t}, i.e., the second-order cone in Rni+1​.

 

Matrix norm minimization

Let A(x)=A0+x1A1+⋯+xnAn, where Ai∈Rp×q. The unconstrained problem, minimizing ∥A(x)∥2, where ∥⋅∥2​ denotes the spectral norm (maximum singular value), is a convex problem. (See Example 3.11, Norm of a matrix.)

Using the fact ∥A∥2≤s if and only if ATA⪯s2I (and s≥0), we can express the problem in the form

minimizessubject toA(x)TA(x)⪯sI.

Since A(x)TA(x)−sI is matrix convex in (x,s), this is a convex optimization problem with a single q×q matrix inequality constraint.

We can also formulate the problem using a single LMI of size (p+q)×(p+q), using the fact that

ATA⪯t2I (and t≥0)⟺[tIAATtI]⪰0.

This results in the SDP

minimizetsubject to[tIA(x)A(x)TtI]⪰0.
